generif.text: Overexpression of WISP2 is associated with breast cancer
disruption of WISP-2 signaling by use of antisense oligomers caused a significant reduction in breast tumor cell proliferation
WISP2 was overexpressed in gastrointestinal peptide-independent ACTH-independent macronodular adrenal hyperplasia.
regulation of phosphorylation of ER-alpha and EGFR may play critical roles in EGF-induced transcriptional activation of WISP-2 gene in breast tumor cells
These data demonstrate that the expression of WISP2 is synergistically upregulated in RA synovial fibroblasts by estrogen and WNT pathways, and suggest an involvement in the pathology of the disease.
Results suggest that WISP-2 could be a reliable independent marker and that down-regulation or loss of the WISP-2 gene may be associated with the development of salivary gland tumors.

WISP-2/CCN5 is a novel signaling molecule that critically participates in the mitogenic action of PMA on noninvasive, WISP-2/CCN5-positive breast tumor cells through PKCalpha-dependent, multiple molecular signal transduction pathways.
Data suggest WISP-2/CCN5 silencing may be a critical event during differentiation and progression of pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

WISP-2 had greater levels of expression in node-positive tumors; higher levels in both moderate and poor prognostic groups compared with the good prognostic group; greater level in both grade 2 and 3 when compared with grade 1.
WISP-2/CCN5 is an important regulator involved in the maintenance of a differentiated phenotype in breast tumor epithelial cells and may play a role in tumor cell invasion and metastasis
Loss of CCN5 is associated with gain of oncogenic function of p53 mutants invasiveness in breast cancer

CCN5 mRNA and protein level was almost undetectable in poorly differentiated breast cancers compared with the moderately or well-differentiated samples and its expression inversely correlated with lymph node positivity.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
The CCN5/WISP2 were downregulated in paired comparisons of plexiform neurofibroma and malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor.

WISPs may play important but contrasting roles in colorectal cancer with WISP-1 appearing to act as a factor stimulating aggressiveness, WISP-2 as a tumour suppressor and WISP-3 having no definable beneficial or detrimental role
CCN5 represses expression of genes associated with epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) as well as expression of key components of the transforming growth factor beta (TGF-beta) signaling pathway.
Studies suggest a novel regulatory pathway exists through which CCN5 exerts its anti-invasive function.
WISP2 gene expression is regulated both by obesity and by the region between visceral and subcutaneous adipose tissue.
WISP2 regulates preadipocyte commitment and PPARgamma activation by BMP4.
overexpression of FGFBP1 or loss of WISP-2 expression is closely related to the metastasis, invasion and poor prognosis of gallbladder cancer.
Regulation of invasion by WISP2 may involve the WNT signalling pathway.
We demonstrate that the overexpression of CCN5 in lung fibroblasts suppresses the upregulation in the expression of alpha-SMA and collagen induced by CCN2.

WISP2 exerts dual actions in mesenchymal precursor cells; secreted WISP2 activates canonical WNT and maintains the cells in an undifferentiated state, whereas cytosolic WISP2 regulates adipogenic commitment.
Loss of WISP2 in estrogen-dependent MCF7 human breast cancer cells promotes a stem-like cell phenotype.
WISP2 has a role in regulating tumor cell susceptibility through EMT by inducing the TGF-beta signaling pathway, KLF-4 expression and miR-7 inhibition.

Serum WISP2 correlated directly with fatty acid binding protein 4. Serum SFRP5 did not differ between obese (n=32) vs. nonobese (n=25) PCOS women, but reference women had lower SFRP5 (p<5x10(-6) as compared to both PCOS groups).
Activation of CCN5 may have the therapeutic potential to kill triple-negative breast cancer.
The obtained results indicate that the changes in gene expression in bone marrow progenitor cells can be involved into space flight-induced osteopenia.
Report opposing effects of CCN2 and CCN5 on fibroblast proliferation and transdifferentiation induced by TGF-beta.

Studies indicate that the CYR61 CTGF NOV matricellular proteins (CCN family of proteins) comprises the members CCN1, CCN2, CCN3, CCN4, CCN5 and CCN6 and have been identified in various types of cancer.
CCN3 (Nov) and CCN5 (WISP2) are novel substrates of MMP14.

The authors show that, in triple-negative-breast cancer (TNBC) cells enriched with tumor initiating cells, CCN5 significantly blocks cellular growth via apoptosis, reversing epithelial-mesenchymal-transition-signaling and impairing mammosphere formation, thereby blocking the tumor-forming ability and invasive capacity of these cells.
Results show that WISP2 and beta-catenin were more highly expressed in gastric cancer tissues and seem to correlate with early stage or without metastasis.

by analyzing different estrogen receptor-alpha(ER-a)-positive and ER-a-negative breast cancer cell lines, we defined the role of CCN5 in the leptin-mediated regulation of growth and invasive capacity.
Our findings suggest that activation of WISP2 could be a useful therapeutic strategy for the treatment of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma
CCN5 inhibits proliferation and promotes apoptosis of oral squamous cell carcinoma cells.
WISP2 promotes cell proliferation via targeting ERK and YAP in ovarian cancer cells.
WISP2/IGF1 promotes the survival of DSCs and impairs the cytotoxicity of decidual NK cells.
Protective effect of estrogen receptors (ERalpha/beta) against the intervertebral disc degeneration involves activating CCN5 via the promoter.
Matricellular Protein WISP2 Is an Endogenous Inhibitor of Collagen Linearization and Cancer Metastasis.
Dual roles of WISP2 in the progression of hepatocellular carcinoma: implications of the fibroblast infiltration into the tumor microenvironment.
WISP-2 modulates the induction of inflammatory mediators and cartilage catabolism in chondrocytes.
The carboxyl-terminal TSP1-homology domain is the biologically active effector peptide of matricellular protein CCN5 that counteracts profibrotic CCN2.
Acetylation stabilizes the signaling protein WISP2 by preventing its degradation to suppress the progression of acute myeloid leukemia.
LncRNA TRG-AS1 inhibits bone metastasis of breast cancer by the miR-877-5p/WISP2 axis.
WISP2 downregulation inhibits the osteogenic differentiation of BMSCs in congenital scoliosis by regulating Wnt/beta-catenin pathway.
ERalpha prevents tumorigenesis of both liver and breast cancer cells through CCN5.
SNHG3/WISP2 Axis Promotes Hela Cell Migration and Invasion via Activating Wnt/beta-Catenin Signaling.

interpro.desc: Growth factor receptor cysteine-rich domain superfamily
Insulin-like growth factor binding protein, N-terminal, Cys-rich conserved site

name: cellular communication network factor 5
summary: This gene encodes a member of the WNT1 inducible signaling pathway (WISP) protein subfamily, which belongs to the connective tissue growth factor (CTGF) family. WNT1 is a member of a family of cysteine-rich, glycosylated signaling proteins that mediate diverse developmental processes. The CTGF family members are characterized by four conserved cysteine-rich domains: insulin-like growth factor-binding domain, von Willebrand factor type C module, thrombospondin domain and C-terminal cystine knot-like (CT) domain. The encoded protein lacks the CT domain which is implicated in dimerization and heparin binding. It is 72% identical to the mouse protein at the amino acid level. This gene may be downstream in the WNT1 signaling pathway that is relevant to malignant transformation. Its expression in colon tumors is reduced while the other two WISP members are overexpressed in colon tumors. It is expressed at high levels in bone tissue, and may play an important role in modulating bone turnover. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
